abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
              <jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Dysfunction in inwardly rectifying potassium channel Kir4.1 has been implicated in SeSAME syndrome, an autosomal-recessive (AR), rare, multi-systemic disorder. However, not all neurological, intellectual disability, and comorbid phenotypes in SeSAME syndrome can be mechanistically linked solely to Kir4.1 dysfunction.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>
              <jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>We therefore performed whole-exome sequencing and identified additional genetic risk-elements that might exert causative effects either alone or in concert with Kir4.1 in a family diagnosed with SeSAME syndrome.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>
              <jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Two variant prioritization pipelines based on AR inheritance and runs of homozygosity (ROH), identified two novel homozygous variants in <jats:italic>KCNJ10</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>PI4KB</jats:italic> and five rare homozygous variants in <jats:italic>PVRL4</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>RORC</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>FLG2</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>FCRL1</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>NIT1</jats:italic> and one common homozygous variant in <jats:italic>HSPA6</jats:italic> segregating in all four patients. The novel mutation in <jats:italic>KCNJ10</jats:italic> resides in the cytoplasmic domain of Kir4.1, a seat of phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate (PIP2) binding. The mutation altered the subcellular localization and stability of Kir4.1 in patient-specific lymphoblastoid cells (LCLs) compared to parental controls. Barium-sensitive endogenous K<jats:sup>+</jats:sup> currents in patient-specific LCLs using whole-cell patch-clamp electrophysiology revealed membrane depolarization and defects in inward K<jats:sup>+</jats:sup> ion conductance across the membrane, thereby suggesting a loss-of-function effect of <jats:italic>KCNJ10</jats:italic> variant.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>
              <jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Altogether, our findings implicate the role of new genes in SeSAME syndrome without electrolyte imbalance and thereby speculate the regulation of Kir4.1 channel activity by PIP2 and integrin-mediated adhesion signaling mechanisms.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study has been approved by three institutional committees; NIMHANS ethics committee [NIMHANS/2nd IEC (BS and NS DIV)/2016], NIMHANS stem cell research committee (IC-SCR) dated 12 February 2018 and NIMHANS bio-safety committee (NIMHANS/DO/3rd IBSC MEET1NG/2016).

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: We have obtained the consent for publication from all individuals. We would be glad to share this data at any stage when requested.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
